title: BHP defends dividend after profit fall
text:
Tue, Aug 25, 2015, 7:28 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed BHP defends dividend after profit fall AAP â€“ 21 minutes ago View Photo 

Mining giant BHP Billiton has defended its increased dividends and cut spending after annual profit halved to $US6.4 billion. 
One of the world's largest iron ore producers, BHP increased full year dividends by 2.5 per cent to $US1.24 per share despite plunging commodity prices slashing its earnings. 
Underlying profit dropped 52 per cent in the year to June 30, falling just short of market expectations of a $US6.6 billion profit. 
BHP is reducing investment and stretching the capacity of its existing operations to increase volumes at very low costs, and also paid $US1.4 of debt in the year. 
Chief executive Andrew Mackenzie said BHP could maintain a progressive dividend policy due to its productivity and efficiency programs. 
"That commitment is borne out of our belief that we can drive further gains in productivity, the strength of our balance sheet and the extreme flexibility and efficiency of our capital investment program," Mr Mackenzie told reporters. 
"Our growth plans are in no way suspended or put off in order to pay this dividend," he said. 
BHP plans to reduce capital expenditure in the next two financial years, cutting spending from $US11 billion in the 2014/15 year to $US7 billion by 2016/17. 
The company expects unit costs in its West Australian iron ore business to fall to US$15 per tonne in 2015/16, from US$19 in the previous year, but did not say whether job losses would be associated with the reductions. 
Falling iron ore, copper, coal and petroleum prices wiped $US16.4 billion from its underlying earnings in 2014/15, with iron ore the main culprit, as BHP's realised prices fell 41 per cent from the prior year. 
Mr Mackenzie said prices would remain volatile due to economic reforms in China, and said BHP had lowered its forecast for peak Chinese steel demand in the mid-2020s. 
The company expects improvements in the Chinese economy in the second half of 2015 following recent market volatility. 
"We've been at this game for decades and we've made forecasts about the development of China and we've been very sound business decisions off those forecasts that have proved to be correct," he said. 
BHP would also keep an eye on acquisition opportunities in the copper and oil and gas sectors, but would not pay too much, he said. 
Fat Prophets resources analyst David Lennox said BHP's balance sheet remained very strong and cash flow was still robust. 
"They have got the capacity to pay the dividend, they are sticking with their progressive policy and in this sort of environment that should give investors a little bit of heart," Mr Lennox said. 
China's steel production would be adequate to keep Australian iron ore production rolling for a long time to come, he added. 
BHP BILLITON HIT BY PLUNGING PRICES 
* Net profit down 86pct to $US1.9b 
* Underlying profit down 52pct to $US6.4b 
* Final dividend steady at 62 US cents 
BREAKDOWN OF BHP'S PERFORMANCE 
* Iron ore profit down 49pct to $US6.9b 
* Copper profit down 35pct to $US3.4b 
* Petroleum and potash loss of $US985m
